article.title: Compiling and Calling Routines for XPath from R and LLVM
article.para:
Consider an artificial example to start. We have an XML document of the form
<doc> <value>1</value> <value>2</value> <value>3</value> ... <value>300</value> </doc>
We want to identify the value elements for which the value of the fibonacci function is greater than 10 when we call the fibonacci function with the content of the value element. In other words, we want to
get the value of each value as a number
pass it in a call to fib()
determine if the result is greater than 10
We could do this in R by extracting all of the value nodes and then extracting their values and computing the fibonacci number for each then filtering the nodes based on those values.

We can then use this in our R XPath calls. We first load the XML package, and the newly created DSO and then get the address of the xpathFib routine:
library(XML) dyn.load("fib.so") fib.ptr = getNativeSymbolInfo('xpathFib')$address

Now we can use this xpathFib routine in a call to getNodeSet(), xpathSApply(), xpathApply(), etc. via the xpathFuns parameter. We provide a list of named elements, with the names being those to use in the XPath expression, and the value being the address of a native routine or an R function.

So we can filter our value nodes in place with
doc = xmlParse("doc.xml") cc = getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = fib.ptr))

section.title: LLVM
section.para:
Now that we have seen how we could make the fibonacci routine available to XPath in C, we will mimic this using LLVM. We will not discuss how we generated the LLVM version of fib and xpathFib. That is discussed in the LLVM compilation chapter and package. For now, we can just take a short-cut and convert the fib.c C file we wrote into IR with
clang -emit-llvm -S -O2 fib.c -o fib.ll `xml2-config --cflags`

We want to do essentially the analogous steps we did for the C code. We want to load the xpathFib routine. We load the Rllvm package and parse the fib.ll module.
library(Rllvm) m = parseIR("fib.ll")
When we created the .so, we linked the compiled C code with the libxml2 library. However, here we haven't done a linking step. So we have references in our xpathFib routine to routines xmlXPathPopNumber, xmlXPathNewFloat and valuePush that are in libxml2. These are available via the XML.so from the XML R package. So we can find the addresses of these and provide them to LLVM to essentially do the linking:
llvmAddSymbol("xmlXPathPopNumber", "xmlXPathNewFloat", "valuePush")

Again, since we haven't explicitly linked code, we have to provide LLVM with a run-time engine or context.
ee = ExecutionEngine(m)
As we did with the C code, we get the address of the xpathFib routine, but this time in the LLVM module:
llfib.ptr = getPointerToFunction(m$xpathFib, ee)@ref
We can pass this routine address via the xpathFuns parameter of getNodeSet as we did for the C code
ll = getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = llfib.ptr))

identical(sapply(cc, xmlValue), sapply(ll, xmlValue))
cc and ll are identical if run on the same instance of doc.

para.r:code: B = 30 ll.tm = system.time(replicate(B, getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = llfib.ptr)))) cc.tm = system.time(replicate(B, getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = fib.ptr)) ))

section.para:
fib = function(n) if(n < 2) n else fib(n-1) + fib(n-2) fib(10) # 55
rr = getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = fib)) identical(rr, cc)
rr.tm = system.time(replicate(B, getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = fib)) )) rr.tm/ll.tm
Giving a factor of 158.

section.title: Compiling fib and xpathFib
section.para: The RLLVMCompile package can handle the simple fib() function once it is told that the input is an integer (rather than a numeric scalar).

There are several ways for us to generate the xpathFib() routine in LLVM. One is that we create an R function that knows all about XPath and the available routines, e.g., xmlXPathPopBoolean, xmlXPathPopNumber, xmlXPathPopString, xmlXPathPopNodeSet and xmlXPathPopExternal and xmlXPathReturnNumber, etc.

Another approach is that we write the C function as an R function and use RLLVMCompile to translate that to LLVM. This is probably simplest as it is most general. However, we need to be able to provide the types of the parameters and return values of each of the routines we reference. We can use RCIndex for that.

We'll see that xmlXPathReturnNumber is a macro that calls valuePush(). That returns an int value. However, our xpathFib routine should return a void. So we would tell RLLVMCompile to have it return void and not the value from xmlXPathReturnNumber.

To get the type of the parameters, we read the xpath header files. We create a simple xpath.c file
#include <libxml/xpath.h> #include <libxml/xpathInternals.h>
library(RCIndex) # Compute the include directories cflags = system("xml2-config --cflags", intern = TRUE) flags = strsplit(cflags, " ")[[1]] incs = gsub("-I", "", flags[grep("^-I", flags)]) tu = createTU("xpath.c", incs) rr = getRoutines(tu)
We find the return type of xmlXPathPopNumber
xp = rr$xmlXPathPopNumber getName(xp$returnType)
Next, we get the type of the ctxt parameter:
cxtTy = getCanonicalType(getType(xp@params[[1]])) isPointerType(ctxtTy)
Importantly, it is an opaque pointer.

To determine the return type of the function, we would look for the return type of xmlXPathReturnNumber(). This is not listed in the routines.
tu2 = createTU("xpath.c", incs, options = RCIndex:::CXTranslationUnit_DetailedPreprocessingRecord)
k = function() { ans = list(); function(cur, ...) if(getName(cur) == "xmlXPathReturnNumber") ans <<- c(ans, cur)} zz = k() tu2 = createTU("xpath.c", incs, options = RCIndex:::CXTranslationUnit_DetailedPreprocessingRecord) m = environment(zz)$ans[[1]] toks = getCursorTokens(m) getParams(toks)
So we would replace
xmlXPathReturnNumber(ctxt, fib(num))
with
valuePush(ctxt, xmlXPathNewFloat( fib(num)) )
So we are doing what the pre-processor is doing.

Given the nature of the XPath wrapper functions, it is perhaps simplest to generate the wrapper routine NOT using RLLVMCompile. Instead, we'll write a function that takes an R function and some type information and generates the wrapper function as an LLVM Function.

para.r:code: library(Rllvm) m = parseIR("fibOnly.ll") m2 = clone(m) xp = genXPathWrapper(m2$fib)
doc = xmlParse("doc.xml") ll = getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ fib(number(.)) > 10 ]", xpathFuns = list(fib = xp))

section.title: Character Strings
section.para: Here we write a routine that maps a month number to its name. Then we compare the month name to April. This is not an intelligent way of doing the XPath query. However, it illustrates wrapping a routine that returns a string - const char *.

Again, we write the routine in C and convert it to IR so that we can skip that part. However, we could write an R function such as
monthName = function(num) MonthNames[num]
and then translate that to IR very easily.

As before, we read the IR and clone the module.
library(Rllvm) m = parseIR("fibOnly.ll") m2 = clone(m)
We generate the XPath wrapper routine in the m2 module
source("genXPathWrapper.R") mn = genXPathWrapper(m2$monthName)
We load the XML package and its DSO and then register the routines the module (m2) uses that come from that DSO:
library(XML) llvmAddSymbol("xmlXPathPopNumber", "xmlXPathNewCString", "valuePush")
We create the execution engine/context and find the address in memory of our newly created XPath wrapper routineL
ee = ExecutionEngine(m2) xp = getPointerToFunction(m2$xpathmonthName, ee)@ref
Finally, we pass the address of the routine via the xpathFuns parameter and process the mon elements in the document.
doc = xmlParse("doc2.xml") ll = getNodeSet(doc, "//mon[ month(number(.)) = 'April' ]", xpathFuns = list(month = xp))
ll

section.title: DoubleType log() routine
section.para: We wrote log(double val) return(log(val)) in the C code which is infinitely recursive. So we we need a name mylog for our implementation of log. See below for using the built-in log routine directly.

para.r:code:
library(Rllvm) m = parseIR("fibOnly.ll") m2 = clone(m)
source("genXPathWrapper.R") mn = genXPathWrapper(m2$mylog)
library(XML) llvmAddSymbol("xmlXPathPopNumber", "xmlXPathNewFloat", "valuePush")
ee = ExecutionEngine(m2) xp = getPointerToFunction(m2$xpathmylog, ee)@ref
doc = xmlParse("doc.xml") ll = getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ log(number(.)) > 3.0 ]", xpathFuns = list(log = xp))

section.title: Built-in log() Routine
section.para:
Here we use the built-in log() function directly. So create a wrapper to the libc log routine.
library(Rllvm) m = parseIR("fibOnly.ll") m2 = clone(m)
source("genXPathWrapper.R") Function("log", DoubleType, DoubleType, m2) mn = genXPathWrapper(m2$log)
library(XML) llvmAddSymbol("xmlXPathPopNumber", "xmlXPathNewFloat", "valuePush", "log")
Note our new function is called xpathlog and not xpathmylog. However, we can also pass the returned function from genXPathWrapper() directly
ee = ExecutionEngine(m2) xp = getPointerToFunction(m2$xpathlog, ee)@ref xp = getPointerToFunction(mn, ee)@ref
So we can now use this routine in an XPath query:
doc = xmlParse("doc.xml") ll = getNodeSet(doc, "//value[ log(number(.)) > 3.0 ]", xpathFuns = list(log = xp)) length(ll) all(log(as.numeric(sapply(ll, xmlValue))) > 3.0) table(log(as.numeric(sapply(getNodeSet(doc, "//value"), xmlValue))) > 3.0)
